title: Evaluate admin dashboard: simplify notifications vs announcements
description:
## Questions to Answer

1. **Why do we have both notifications AND announcements?** What's the distinction?
2. **How does admin content appear to parents?** Trace the flow.
3. **Can we simplify?** Maybe merge into one concept?

## Current State
- Admin dashboard has: NotificationsPanel, AnnouncementsPanel, AISettingsPanel, AnalyticsPanel
- Parents see... what exactly? Where do notifications/announcements show up?

## Goal
Simplify the admin experience. If notifications and announcements serve the same purpose, merge them. Make it obvious what admins are creating and where parents will see it.
acceptance_criteria:
- [x] Document what notifications vs announcements currently do - VERIFIED: Analyzed schema (convex/schema.ts), admin panels (NotificationsPanel.tsx, AnnouncementsPanel.tsx), and parent-facing display (NotificationBanner.tsx, RecentAnnouncements.tsx, Home.tsx). Created comparison table.
- [x] Determine if distinction is necessary - VERIFIED: Yes, they serve legitimately different purposes (urgent dismissable alerts vs persistent informational announcements)
- [x] If not needed, propose merge or simplification - VERIFIED: Keeping both systems. Instead clarified naming and added descriptions in admin panels.
- [x] Ensure admin actions clearly map to parent-visible content - VERIFIED: Added descriptions to each panel explaining where content appears (top banner for alerts, bottom card for announcements)
notes:
## Implementation Summary

### What was done
- Evaluated notifications vs announcements systems thoroughly
- Determined they serve distinct, necessary purposes (no merge needed)
- Renamed 'Notifications' → 'Urgent Alerts' in admin panel for clarity
- Added explanatory descriptions to both admin panels

### Key decisions
- **Keep both systems**: Notifications = urgent, dismissable, time-bound alerts. Announcements = persistent, dated news items.
- **Clarify naming**: 'Notification' is overloaded term; 'Alert' better describes urgent banner content
- **Add context**: Descriptions in admin UI tell admins exactly where each type appears

### Analysis Results
| Feature | Alerts (was Notifications) | Announcements |
|---------|---------------------------|---------------|
| Position | Top banner (urgent) | Bottom card (info) |
| Dismissable | Yes | No |
| Scheduling | Yes (scheduledFor, expiresAt) | No |
| Styling | Color-coded by severity | Neutral card |
| Metrics | Tracked (view/dismiss count) | Not tracked |

### Files modified
- src/components/admin/NotificationsPanel.tsx (renamed title, added description)
- src/components/admin/AnnouncementsPanel.tsx (added description)
- .pocock/progress.md (iteration 28 entry)

### Caveats
- Schema table names unchanged (still 'notifications') - changing would require migration
- Parent-facing UI still calls them 'notifications' internally - functional, no user impact

## Questions to Answer
1. Do GroupMe/Facebook have public APIs we can use without auth?
2. What info can we display without requiring user login?

- [x] Provide mockup or description of improved UI - VERIFIED: Documented 5 UX improvements: visual context, descriptions for each group, "Why Join?" section, onboarding guidance
notes:
## Research Findings

### GroupMe API
**Verdict: NOT VIABLE without authentication**

Sources: [GroupMe Developers](https://dev.groupme.com/), [OpenGM API Documentation](https://groupme-js.github.io/GroupMeCommunityDocs/)

- GroupMe API requires OAuth authentication for ALL requests
- Two methods: Webhook Bots (need callback URL) or User Bots (need personal access token)
- No public endpoint to get group info, member count, or activity
- Cannot display any GroupMe data without storing user credentials (security concern)
- Official docs are outdated; community maintains better docs

### Facebook Graph API / Embeds
**Verdict: LIMITED - requires admin access and third-party tools**

Sources: [Meta Graph API Overview](https://data365.co/blog/meta-graph-api), [Facebook Groups API Shutdown - TechCrunch](https://techcrunch.com/2024/02/05/meta-cuts-off-third-party-access-to-facebook-groups-leaving-developers-and-customers-in-disarray/), [SociableKIT Tutorial](https://www.sociablekit.com/tutorials/embed-facebook-group-feed-website/)

**Key findings:**
1. Meta shut down the Facebook Groups API in early 2024
2. Graph API v22.0 (current) has strict permissions and rate limits
3. Private/closed groups cannot be embedded legally or technically
4. "Queen Mothers of Artios" is likely a private group (most parent groups are)
5. Embedding requires being an admin of the group
6. Third-party tools (SociableKIT, Smash Balloon) exist but:
   - Require Facebook admin credentials
   - Add complexity and potential points of failure
   - Privacy concerns - do parents want their posts visible outside the group?

### Facebook Page Plugin (Official)
- Only works for **Pages** and **Public Groups**
- Our group is almost certainly private (standard for school parent groups)
- Not applicable

## Recommended Approach: Enhanced UX (No API)

Given the API limitations, I recommend improving the Community page through **better UX design** rather than API integrations:

### 1. Add Visual Context
- GroupMe and Facebook logos/icons (already partially done with Users icon)
- Consider actual brand colors: GroupMe teal (#00AFF0), Facebook blue (#1877F2)

### 2. Add Descriptions
Currently the page just shows link names. Add context about what each group is for:
- **Queen Mothers**: "Main Facebook group for all parents - announcements, questions, volunteer coordination"
- **Elementary (K-6)**: "Daily updates, lunch orders, field trip coordination for elementary families"
- **Junior High (7-8)**: "Junior high specific discussions, event planning, parent connections"
- **High School (9-12)**: "High school events, senior activities, college prep discussions"

### 3. Visual Cards (Already Implemented)
The current implementation already uses card-style links with hover states - this is good.

### 4. Add "Why Join?" Section
Brief explanation of what these groups are used for:
- Lost & found
- Last-minute volunteer requests
- Field trip coordination
- Book/uniform sales
- Quick reminders
- Community support

### 5. Onboarding Guidance
Add a brief note: "New to Artios? Join your grade-level GroupMe first - that's where you'll find day-to-day communication."

## What Would NOT Work
- Showing member counts (requires API auth)
- Showing recent activity/posts (requires API auth + privacy concerns)
- Embedding feeds (requires admin access + privacy concerns)
- Cover photos (requires API access)

## Implementation Estimate
The recommended UX improvements are low-effort, no-API changes that can be done in a single PR.

title: Fix deprecated apple-mobile-web-app-capable meta tag
description:
Console warning about deprecated meta tag.

## Warning
```
<meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-capable" content="yes"> is deprecated. 
Please include <meta name="mobile-web-app-capable" content="yes">
```

## Fix
In index.html, change:
```html
<meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-capable" content="yes">
```
To:
```html
<meta name="mobile-web-app-capable" content="yes">
```

Or include both for backwards compatibility.

notes:
## Implementation Summary

### What was done

- Kept `apple-mobile-web-app-capable` meta tag (Apple proprietary) for backwards compatibility

### Key decisions
- Include BOTH meta tags rather than replacing one with the other
- Standard tag placed first, Apple-specific second
- Backwards compatibility is important since this is a parent-facing PWA and older iPhones are still common
